headline.main: THE FRENCH VIEW OF THE QUESTION.; A Semi-Official Indication The French Unfriendly to the United States Gen. Scott's Letter Miscellaneous.

docs.lead_paragraph: Within a few years no event has so exclusively occupied the attention of the public and the press in France, as what is here called the Anglo-American conflict. It is the one sole subject of conversation in financial and commercial circles, and the columns of the Press are one-half given up to it.

docs.snippet: About seventy or eighty Americans, resident in Berlin, dined together in that city a few days before the departure of the America, at Arnim's Hotel, to celebrate their national custom of the harvest home, or autumnal feast. The following account of...
docs.lead_paragraph: About seventy or eighty Americans, resident in Berlin, dined together in that city a few days before the departure of the America, at Arnim's Hotel, to celebrate their national custom of the harvest home, or autumnal feast. The following account of the proceedings is a condensation of an ampler report which has been received:

docs.snippet: Among the veracious reports on the health of our troops, with which it is the ambition of some of our cotemporaries to enrich their columns, one of the most original has recently appeared in the Tribune. That journal gravely stated on Saturday that...
docs.lead_paragraph: Among the veracious reports on the health of our troops, with which it is the ambition of some of our cotemporaries to enrich their columns, one of the most original has recently appeared in the Tribune. That journal gravely stated on Saturday that three of our invalid soldiers at Port Royal had been "frozen to death" in their tents.

headline.main: NEWS FROM FORTRESS MONROE.; Excitement Relative to Late Southern News --The Late Conflagration at Charleston Winter Quarters for the Troops--Danger of Weakening Gen. Wool's Command, &c.

docs.lead_paragraph: There is considerable excitement here over the late Southern news, especially the news from Charleston. Officers and soldiers think that the experience at Charleston is but the prelude to more of the same kind. The rebel Press may very well throw a covering over the real origin of the conflagration, for in doing so it serves the purposes of the rebels,...
